head.title: Eggs Are Just the Start of This Omelet

hedline.hl1: Eggs Are Just the Start of This Omelet

block.p: When customers enter Edie's Lunchonette in Little Silver, N.J., they're in for more than a tasty breakfast or lunch. A trip down memory lane is also included, a journey that goes back to the last century.

The refurbished wooden building that houses the eatery was built about 1889 (according to available records) for use as a general store and post office and became a full-time restaurant in 1930. The dining area provides customers with the old-style charm of wooden floors, pew-like booths, a soda fountain counter and stained glass.

When customers enter Edie's Lunchonette in Little Silver, N.J., they're in for more than a tasty breakfast or lunch. A trip down memory lane is also included, a journey that goes back to the last century.

The refurbished wooden building that houses the eatery was built about 1889 (according to available records) for use as a general store and post office and became a full-time restaurant in 1930. The dining area provides customers with the old-style charm of wooden floors, pew-like booths, a soda fountain counter and stained glass.

Hardy morning and midday meals are served at Edie's, with an array of omelets that are much in demand. A chalkboard menu above the counter is filled with interesting omelet options including jelly, porkroll, and vegetable fillings.

A decision about the numerous choices is made somewhat easier by the popular Garbage Omelet. What's in it? Bacon, onions, green pepper, cheeses and other ingredients summed up by a notation on the menu as "all of the above."

The result is a plump omelet that is barely contained on a large plate. The order includes Edie's Fries--waffle fries cooked in canoloa oil and amazingly grease-free-- in addition to toast and a cup of coffee.

Those who frequently dine at Edie's, along with the staff, always keep an eye out for the boss. Not Lori Pappas who manages the business (named after Edie Bacigalupi, a previous owner), but the Boss himself, the musician Bruce Springsteen, who lives nearby and is a frequent customer. However, diners sang the praises of Edie's long before Springsteen arrived on the scene.
EDIE'S LUNCHEONETTE, 164 Rumson Road, Little Silver, N.J. (908) 842-9647. Hours: 6 A.M. to 3 P.M. Monday through Friday; 6 A.M. to 2 P.M. Saturday.
